Explaining the Fourier heat equations using the Fourier series was a bit of a problem. Here, to convert a temperature field to a vector field, the gradient vector field must be obtained using the nabla operator. Then the divergence giving the heat change in this vector field must be calculated. Finally, this heat exchange must be equalized to the 1st derivative of the temperature with respect to time. Ad partial/ordinary naming. In physics we got Hamiltonian (H; generalized energy) which is a function of position, momentum and time. We may want to differentiate it with respect to any of the three arguments separately. The problem is with time because both position and momentum are functions of time. Then ∂H/∂t see only explicit time dependence of H, while dH/dt see also "via position/velocity" time dependence.

Even better, in the Lagrange's equations we got both partial and ordinary derivatives :)

While watching this video, I was considering how you do your animations. I am a huge fan, and stumbled across this series as part of my quest to watch all of your content. I have noticed you have a pretty consistent animation for drawing straight lines - that is, the accelerations are pretty constant and look the same, have the same energy when looked at, etc etc

But then I got to thinking: how in the world would someone define that line-drawing behavior? Should it draw at a fixed velocity, always drawing the same proportion of the line with each time step? Should it accelerate and then decelerate, like the one you use? Maybe it should start moving quickly, but end slowly? I have no idea! I don’t think anyone could just pop into whatever animation software, draw a nice velocity curve, and say “yes, this is what I want because I have solved the problem of animating lines.” Humans can’t pull that arbitrarily out of a hat, and math doesn’t have those answers.

But then I realized, if you look at an example animation - well, everything changes. That animation is way too slow; I think it would look better faster. Going at a constant rate is boring, add some energy with dynamic speeds.
Humans cannot just generate numbers like that and expect them to work. But what they can do is look at a preexisting condition and say if it’s too high or too low, if it’s too fast or too slow - indeed, we are differential equations generators ourselves!

Being a bit pedantic here, but \nabla^2 is the Hessian of a function T, i.e. for a covariant derivative (or connection) ∇, the Hessian is the two times iterated covariant derivative of function. The Laplace operator you mean is actually defined as the trace of the Hessian \tr\nabla^2, i.e. the contraction of the covariant derivative of the differential of any smooth function, which gives in particular the sum of squares of the partial derivatives on IR^n.

In short: ∆ ≠ ∇^2
Highlighting the necessary.

Say I have a rod that has a linear variation of temperature between its ends. Say, for example a 100 mm long rod with T=0C for X=0mm, T=100C for X=100mm and T=x for any point between those ends.
WILL THE TEMPERATURE OF THE ROD REMAIN CONSTANT????
Intuitively, obviously not. The heat will flow from the hotter zones to the cooler zones until all the rod is at the same intermediate temperature.
But, the partial derivative of the temperature with the position on the rod is constant (=1) and hence the second derivative is zero, which given the equality would mean that the partial derivative of the temperature with time is also zero and hence the temperature (at any point x) doesn't change with time.

The total derivative d vs partial ∂ notation thing is only super important once you start trying to consider physical things with actual movement.. Otherwise they're the same -- by definition of things not physically moving.

Once things DO move, however.. they are not. You need to know what the material derivative is, or at least the distinction between the total derivative dt (changes due to any change with time, including changes caused by having a velocity for a moving thing) and the partial derivative ∂t (changes due just to that variable alone).

This comes up in fluid dynamics, but it is most irritating in electrodynamics, where the dt terms in Faradays' Law of induction and the implicit velocity of net charge in Ampere's circuital law are neglected in the most commonly taught form of 'Maxwell's Equations' (which are actually Oliver Heaviside's nondimensional rewrite of Maxwell's actual Equations). Consequently they need to have the Lorentz force law tacked on before also applying ye olde Newton's equations. Numerically you have to use a really ugly 'back and forth' method if substantial charge is moving, ie, enough that the thing(s) whose motion you are trying to solve itself/themselves cause a change to the spatial charge density rho, or the spatial current density vector J, as they move.

Maxwell was interested only if there was a solution which would enable electrical energy transfer between disconnected wires over an intervening space, without any physical velocities allowed.
In this case only is it reasonable to simply assert that only partial ∂/∂t terms are needed, and are equivalent to the total derivative. This works out well when you also discover/consider typical electron drift velocities in wires --- practically motionless! mm/hr etc.

So it's good for antenna design (you can solve for a time-dependant current in different [but fixed in space] wires, without going 'back and forth' with Newtons -- you can link it to a circuit equation using circuit inductance to eliminate worrying about inertia), and hopelessly useless for electric motor / solenoid design. (Unless you 'cheat' numerically, by swapping back and forth between M-E and Newton's laws of motion on every timestep -- but even there, it's only really good for equipment design where significant vibrations of similar frequencies to the EM waves don't occur, or where there is moving charge, but it's an insignificant proportion of the total unbalanced space charge, as in high energy particle accelerators and vacuum tubes of not-too-high beam currents).



Interesting further reading: Hertzian Electrodynamics also Weber's Electrodynamics, which also collapses the electrico/magneto-static fields down to a single unified force field (parameterized in phase space, as the force depends on the velocity of the charge which experience it, at every position coordinate).

Especially also Thomas E. Phipps Jr's books -- where he points out in great detail that Einstein was totally wrong to try to apply relative motion to Maxwell's Equations, and the contradictions and paradoxes that result should come as no surprise.

He also points out that time dilation is certainly a thing, but that there's no reason all observers couldn't agree to use the one clock -- modulo some relativistic correction factor, and this is indeed the case (or GPS would probably not work). He also shows that with any optical continuous wave interferometry system you should not expect to observe any 'frame dragging', but that with a ring configuration, excited with brief counter-propagating pulses, you sure can build a laser-gyroscope without moving parts -- very sensitive to rotation about an axis perpendicular to the plane in which the ring area is.


Pick any engineering text book on electric motor mechanical design, and you'll probably find the relevant math hasn't actually changed at all in the last century -- it's still Faraday's / Ampere's, and not M-E.

Yet Phipps couldn't get papers published on this -- was too "Heretical". Hence the books "Heretical Verities" and "Old physics for new".

I'm not sure about all his conclusions, in particular I feel that electrodynamics needs to break down into a Quantum-compatible 'covering' model, but I could see how that might work.

I feel like there is a (1/dx)^2 term hidden in the alpha coefficient around 10:20. This term also reflects the fact that the influence of neighboring points (on the point of interest) decreases as we move farther away.

Heat doesn't flow. Heat is not an internal property. You can't have a piece of metal with heat distributed across it.

I am aware that these are very common things to say, but they are wrong and simply serve to confuse discussions about heat.

Heat, like work, is a process. The language about heat was developed at time when we didn't understand what it was, and today heat and internal energy seem to be used interchangeably. But we should update our language to reflect our updated understanding. Just like objects do work and have work done on them, objects do heat and have heat done on them. They don't have heat.

The heat equation describes how temperature flows, not how heat flows. Since no work is being done, the flow of temperature (more precisely, the flow of internal energy) is heat. So we can say the heat equation describes how regions of a material do heat on other regions.

For anyone who is interested in why the change in notation for the (partial) derivative is necessary. In this case the two operations are the same, but the "partial d/dt" means the derivative only with respect to t, if you would use the "total d/dt " (with normal d) you would also have to derive the x-Coordiante with respect to t. Obviosly the pure x coordinate is not dependant on t in any way, but there are functions with more than one parameter where these parameters are dempendant on each other. Then we have a real difference between the "total d/dt" and "partial d/dt".

Not trying to nitpick, but partial derivative can sometimes be significantly different from full derivative if variables are dependent. An example:
f(x, t) = x * t
now assume that x() is a function of t itself:
x(t) = 21 * t
if you get partial derivative of f() over t, you get:
∂f(x, t)/∂t = x
full derivative, however, is
df(x, t)/dt = d(21 * t * t)/dt = 42 * t


this can be quite important in case of Lagrangian mechanics for example, where L=L(q(t), dq/dt(t), t) and every variable inherently depends on time so that dL/dt is a different thing from ∂L/∂t

I also find it really satisfying how the nabla operator ∇ can be thought of as a vector of differential operators ∇ = (d/dx, d/dy, d/dz). With this you can think of ∇f as the "scalar product" (df/dx, df/dy, df/dz) with the function f, and ∇² as the "dot product" with itself: ∇² = d/dx * d/dx + d/dy * d/dy + d/dz * d/dz = d²/d x² + d²/dy² + d²/dz², which in turn means ∇²f = d²f/d x² + d²f/dy² + d²f/dz². It's so nice how the notation just works as if ∇ was an ordinary vector!

This is my guess about the connection between the fourier series, and the heat equation.

If you'll try to solve the heat equation with an initial state of a sine wave (Asin(wx)), you might notice that the second derivative in respect to X equals to the minus of the function's value, times a constant (w^2). Which means that the change in the temperature (T) will be the minus of T times another constant (alpha*w^2). For such an ODE, the solution is an exponential decay(C*exp(-alpha*w^2*t)), so you can guess that the solution to the heat equation in this case will be Asin(wx)*exp(-alpha*w^2*t), and you can try and see that it satisfies the heat equation. And if the initial state is the sum of two different sine waves, the solution will be the sum of the solutions of each individual sine wave (because of the linearity of the PDE). So if I represent a function as a series of sine wave, you get a solution (which can still be an infinite sum of sine waves, multiplied by exponentials, so I don't know how it really helps, but still, this is the how far I got, without actually knowing too much about PDEs specifically, and DEs in general), so if you have anything else, I will be glad to hear it, because I don't have the patience to wait for another week, I will probably lose my sanity before then.

I the first place want to thank you for the mind-blowing videos in general. I have a request for a followup video after partial differential equations with Fourier. To solve partial differential equations I have learned the following mind-blowing steps:
1) Separate the partial differential equation in stationary,
2) Solve the stationary part,
3) Solve the in-stationary part,
4) Calculation of the Fourier constants with the theory of Sturm-Liouville.

Btw this one sentence literally reflects what is on that the equation " the point where the Temperature distribution curves, it tends to change quickly" we have studied how second order derivatives can reveal if points are actually Maxima or minima. That equation tells you that story. At each local minima/ Maxima the temperature changes quickly over time in proportion to its second order derivative

(*The rigorous form of the equation requires you to leave the alpha split, i.e. ro x c x dT/dt = d/dx (lambda dT/dx), as lambda in general is a function of T, or even space in nonuniform materials. We neglect that usually as with numerical solutions you can update lambda locally... As for the derivation - The derivation using 1.st law of thermodynamics, the definition of the Fourier heat flux and the divergence theorem is rather straightforward: the time rate of change of the internal energy accumulated in a infinitesimal volume of the substance, is equal to the net efflux of heat through the surface of this volume element. The later can then be turned into its divergence with the integral on both sides being over the infinitesimal volume, then both sides integrals can drop as the infinitesimal volume is arbitrary, and you are left with the differential equation.)

I have never seen this equation before (thumbnail), given I'm an Electrician, not a Mechanic, but dued to how it is stated there, I think it makes a very clear sense. The speed with what the temperature of a given point is varying (the variation of the variation, it's not an "acceleration", really, once this is temperature, but its analogue), is directly proportional to its own variation in time -- the change in temperature at one point of something is a multiple of its increase or decrease of temperature.
And thinking about that conclusion, makes sense, once the cooler something gets, the slower it keeps cooling down, and the hotter it already is, easier to get even more.

Next up, we'll look at how to solve this with Fourier series, including some discussion of boundary conditions. Stay tuned!

Edit: I see a number of questions about changes at the boundary, so maybe I’ll add a quick note. For example, some of you ask if a function with constant non-zero slope is stable. Indeed, this is something that needs to be specified for a well-defined solution, so good question! The heat equation as described here only describes the interior. The easiest boundary condition to work with is when each endpoint is held fixed, e.g. if the ends of the rod were somehow constrained not to change temperature. In that case, straight lines are a stable solution. But other conditions can be specified too, as you’ll see!
